data.title: VS Code crashing when opening file using Open File/Save
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home (Version 1607, Build 14393)

Steps to Reproduce:

I am administrator on my computer. Since I noticed the error, I have uninstalled VS Code, then downloaded the latest version and reinstalled it. 

1. Open VS Code from the start menu (doesn't matter if run as administrator or not)
2. Use Ctrl+O or Open File
3. Notice the file explorer pops up, but closes within < 1 second along with VS Code

The same can be seen when trying to save a new file (Ctrl+S/Save/Save As) and Open Folder. 

I am able to open files, by using Windows Explorer, and I can also save a file that has been opened. It seems to be an issue with the file explorer that is opened through Open File/Save.

data.title: Fixing sorting of directory and filenames with numbers
data.body:
These changes replace the existing regex-based sorting of filenames and directory names with a call to the [`String.prototype.localeCompare()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/localeCompare) function which supports this natively via the `numeric` option.

Also added some unit test cases for filenames with numbers.

CC: @bpasero

Fixes #17495

data.title: 30 seconds of 100% CPU usage every time my web app makes an ajax request

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Arch Linux (kernel v4.8.8)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Trigger any HTTP request when running the web application I'm working on (sorry, it isn't open source, so I realize that doesn't help a great deal)

The problem is that when I do this, vscode immediately jumps to 100% CPU on one core, and stays there for about 30 seconds before returning to normal. Naturally, this cuts the battery life of my laptop pretty dramatically, to the extent that I am not willing to make vscode my primary editor.
![vscode using 100 cpu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3988775/21951406/c1379aae-d9d3-11e6-8ac5-8767c9fe7a74.png)

Oddly, it is a `code` process that spikes, but performance while using the application does not seem to be affected. At first I thought it might be reindexing files (due to adding a rendered view file or some such), but I tried adding and editing test files, and neither produced the same result (doesn't rule it out, just makes it less a likely suspect in my mind). I have also tried opening it via `code --disable-extensions`, and I still have the same issue, so it's not an extension that's causing the problem.

Here are a few details about my project that might help narrow it down:
- this is a large application (hundreds of thousands of files)
- we use PHP (Laravel) for the back-end, and we're in the process of transitioning to Angular 2 in TypeScript (from an awkward mish-mash of Angular 1, Knockout, and some other stuff that we wrote ourselves in CoffeeScript)
- we use gulp, webpack, npm, and websockets (to name a few more technologies that might be relevant)

To make this even more of a challenge, none of my three coworkers who are using vscode for this project are experiencing this issue, despite having very similar setups. At this point I don't have much hope of there being a clear solution, but I wanted to log this so that if anyone else experiences it, they may be able to add more info that would help diagnose it.

data.title: Allow Expanding Suggestions with Mulitline details
data.body:
Fixes #18490

**Bug**
For completion items with no `documentation` but a long `detail` string, we currently do not allow expansion.

**Fix**
Allow expanding the item if it either has a documentation string or has new line characters in its detail string.

data.title: Use createQueuedSender for all IPC
data.body:
Is this ok, or is there a reason why we don't use this for all IPC channels? I'm seeing this problem with search on Windows. https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/7657

I can add an option somewhere to limit it to the search worker processes if needed.

data.title: Allow spaces before markdown heading
data.body: Fixes #11480

data.title: Simplify markdown paragraph logic
data.body:
Fixes #12946

**Bug**
Out current markdown paragraph matching logic tries to be too fancy. It's acting more like a parser instead of a tokenizer. This prevents us from correctly coloring cases where a block element immediately follows a paragraph

**Fix**
According to the [common mark spec](http://spec.commonmark.org/0.27/#paragraphs), I think we should instead try to parse each new line as a block element.

> A sequence of non-blank lines that cannot be interpreted as other kinds of blocks

The main exception is when the next line contains more than four spaces, which causes it to automatically be included in the previous paragraph instead of being a potential block element:

```md
bla
       * not a **list**
````

data.title: Markdown doesn't support ```c++ blocks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: nightly
- OS Version: linux

Steps to Reproduce:

Create a markdown document and put a c++ code section into it, starting with ```c++. VSCode doesn't highlight it, because there is no c++ match in markdown.tmLanguage.

I suppose to add the following (or something similar, I don't know how that file is created):

```xml
<key>fenced_code_block_cpp</key>
				<dict>
					<key>begin</key>
					<string>(^|\G)(\s*)([`~]{3,})\s*((cpp|c++|cxx)(\s+.*)?$)</string>
					<key>name</key>
					<string>markup.fenced_code.block.markdown</string>
					<key>end</key>
					<string>(^|\G)(\2|\s{0,3})(\3)\s*$</string>
					<key>beginCaptures</key>
					<dict>
						<key>3</key>
						<dict>
							<key>name</key>
							<string>punctuation.definition.markdown</string>
						</dict>
						<key>5</key>
						<dict>
							<key>name</key>
							<string>fenced_code.block.language</string>
						</dict>
						<key>6</key>
						<dict>
							<key>name</key>
							<string>fenced_code.block.language.attributes</string>
						</dict>
					</dict>
					<key>endCaptures</key>
					<dict>
						<key>3</key>
						<dict>
							<key>name</key>
							<string>punctuation.definition.markdown</string>
						</dict>
					</dict>

					<key>patterns</key>
					<array>
						<dict>
							<key>begin</key>
							<string>(^|\G)(\s*)(.*)</string>
							<key>while</key>
							<string>(^|\G)(?!\s*([`~]{3,})\s*$)</string>
							<key>patterns</key>
							<array>
								<dict>
									<key>include</key>
									<string>source.cpp</string>
								</dict>
							</array>
						</dict>
					</array>
				</dict>
```

data.title: Feature request: Put open folder name first in window title (better for thumbnails)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Win 10 64-bit

# Overview: 
Having filename first (rather than folder) in window title bar title makes switching between multiple instances more difficult.

# Abstract: 
Like many developers, I usually have at least 2-3 (often many more) project folders (i.e. code instances) open at the same time, and switch between them. Currently, the window title for each instance is set as follows (at least in Windows version):
[file name] - [folder name] - Visual Studio Code

The problem is that one may be editing a file called 'settings.json' in multiple projects at the same time, making it difficult to quickly discern which tile or thumbnail represents which project when using alt-tab or windows taskbar hover tiles. And if the file name is very long, the folder name may not be visibile at all.

If the folder name were first, it would be much more immediately apparent which tile/thumbnail was which project instance.

# Concerns: 
While I believe that this would be a simple change programmatically, I must admit I have no idea how this would impact my friends on other platforms since I only use Windows. Perhaps someone familiar with the OSx or Linux versions could share their thoughts on this.

data.title: Would like to pass an environment when creating a terminal
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

VSCode Version: 1.9.x

The task framework currently allows to specify environment variables with are set before a task is executed. 
To preserve this feature I need to set an environment as well before starting a shell. I would like to pass an env map (either full or delta) when a terminal is created.

data.title: Crashing immediately on startup

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:

```
 code -v
1.8.1
ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281
```

- OS Version:

```
 system_profiler SPSoftwareDataType
Software:

    System Software Overview:

      System Version: macOS 10.12.2 (16C68)
      Kernel Version: Darwin 16.3.0
```

Also might be worth noting that I have `git@1.8.4` on this machine.

aka Mac OS 10 Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. download the latest `.app` from chrome
2. click on the downloaded zip icon (which uses ??? to unzip it)
3. move the unzipped `.app` to `Applications`
4. double click it
5. crashes immediately

Here is output of `--verbose`.

```sh
(master)  code -v
1.8.1
ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281
(master)  code --verbose
[main 7:12:16 AM] Sending env to running instance...
[main 7:12:16 AM] Sent env to running instance. Terminating...
```

Downgraded to 1.7 and ...

```sh

1.7.2
7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f
(master)  code --verbose

[warn] kq_init: detected broken kqueue; not using.: Undefined error: 0
[main 7:14:40 AM] Sending env to running instance...
[main 7:14:40 AM] Sent env to running instance. Terminating...
```

Upgrading to 1.9.0-insider - and no more immediate crashing!


data.title: ITerminalInstance.dispose results in exception if started with waitOnExit
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

VSCode Version: 1.9.x

- create a terminal instance with waitOnExit = true
- dispose the terminal instance before the shell actually exited

You get the following exception:

```
index.js:34 TypeError: Cannot read property 'writeln' of null
    at TerminalInstance._onPtyProcessExit (terminalInstance.ts:384)
    at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (terminalInstance.ts:362)
    at emitTwo (events.js:111)
    at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:191)
    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:215)
```
